titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Land of Zenj Photograph Collection
titlestmt.author: by Jennifer Meehan and Tina Evans

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:16

did.unittitle: Land of Zenj photograph collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection, assembled by the rare book dealers Jenny Allsworth and Humphrey Winterton, brings together photographs, photograph albums, glass lantern slides, and a lantern projector, which document the Sultanate of Zanzibar and European colonial expansion in East and Central Africa from 1870 to 1914. Also documented are early Arab and Portuguese coastal settlements at Kilwa, Mafia, Pemba, Sofala, and Zanzibar. The collection also represents the work of certain photographers who operated in different parts of the region, including C. Vicente of Dar es Salaam, Coutinho Brothers of Zanzibar and Dar es Salaam, P. De Lord Brothers of Zanzibar and Dar es Salaam, Walther Dobbertin, and A. C. Gomes & Co. of Zanzibar, among others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Allsworth Rare Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Land of Zenj Photograph Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Land of Zenj Photograph Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2008. Descriptive information presented in the narrative and contents list of this finding aid was drawn from the two-volume dealer catalog entitled "The Land of Zenj. The Sultanate of Zanzibar and European Colonial Expansion into East and Central Africa, 1870-1914. An Historical Photographic Record compiled and catalogued, with commentary and annotations, by Jenny Allsworth and Humphrey Winterton." This information has not been verified and is supplied here in order to provide provisional access to the collection and its contents.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: The Land of Zenj
bioghist.p: The Land of Zenj refers to the Arab-controlled region of East Africa, in particular the coastal area, once known as the Zenj Empire. This region flourished for five hundred years from its inception in the 10th century until its demise at the hands of the Portuguese in the early 16th century. The Omani Arabs assumed control of the region from the Portuguese in the 18th century. In 1832, the Iman of Oman, Seyyid Said bin Sultan, made Zanzibar the capital of his East African empire. The opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 led to renewed European interest in the region, and by the early 1890s, Germany, Great Britain, and Portugal were competing for control over different areas within the region. The former Land of Zenj eventually came to comprise the British Protectorates of East Africa, Uganda and Zanzibar (the latter including Mombasa and the rest of the Coastal Strip), British Central Africa, German East Africa, and most of Portuguese East Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection, assembled by the rare book dealers Jenny Allsworth and Humphrey Winterton, brings together photographs, photograph albums, glass lantern slides, and a lantern projector, which document the Sultanate of Zanzibar and European colonial expansion in East and Central Africa from 1870 to 1914. Also documented are early Arab and Portuguese coastal settlements at Kilwa, Mafia, Pemba, Sofala, and Zanzibar. The collection also represents the work of certain photographers who operated in different parts of the region, including C. Vicente of Dar es Salaam, Coutinho Brothers of Zanzibar and Dar es Salaam, P. De Lord Brothers of Zanzibar and Dar es Salaam, Walther Dobbertin, and A. C. Gomes & Co. of Zanzibar, among others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been intellectually organized into eight series: I. Allsworth Rare Books Catalog, 2006; II. Individual Albums and Custom-Boxed Sets, 1880-1927; III. Panoramas and Photographers' Portfolios, 1880-1910; IV. Thematic Collections, 1875-1925; V. People, 1890-1900; VI. Ports and Other Places, 1885-1920; VII. Magic Lantern Slides, 1895-1910; and VIII. The Voyage Out (and Back) Through the Suez Canal, 1869-1937.
This series arrangement reflects the way in which the material is logically organized in the dealer catalog.

Oversize material from all series has been physically organized together in Boxes 16-26. Oversize material is described below in the series of which it forms part intellectually with a note about its physical location, as well as in the listing of oversize boxes.

did.unittitle: Allsworth Rare Books Catalog

"The Land of Zenj. The Sultanate of Zanzibar and European Colonial Expansion into East and Central Africa, 1870-1914. An Historical Photographic Record compiled and catalogued, with commentary and annotations, by Jenny Allsworth and Humphrey Winterton."
"Volume One. Pre-amble and Chapter One (with relative illustrations)."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume provides detailed descriptive information about the collection as a whole and about the material found in Series II of this finding aid.

did.unittitle: "Volume Two. Chapter Two - Seven (with relative illustrations)."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume provides detailed descriptive information about the material found in Series III-VIII of this finding aid.

did.unittitle: Individual albums and custom-boxed sets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this series corresponds to that described in Chapter One of the dealer of the catalog.

did.unittitle: British East Africa: 1 photograph album

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A private snapshot album recording a year's stay, based in Nairobi, by the compiler "C.M.C." and her husband "R.J.C." from November 1904 to November 1905 and containing forty-nine images of various small sizes.

did.unittitle: British East Africa and Uganda Protectorates: 1 photograph album

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album containing sixty original photographs by unidentified photographers, although some may be the work of William D. Young.

did.unittitle: East Africa, Zanzibar and Aden: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: East Africa, Zanzibar and Aden: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album containing twenty-four original photographs and one colored print, all captioned in French and recording scenes on a voyage from Lourenço Marques to Aden, with stops at Dar es Salaam, Tanga, Zanzibar, and Mombasa, in early 1904.

did.unittitle: Eastern Africa: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Eastern Africa: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album containing thirty-nine original photographs and twenty-one postcards, which document an extended visit to Zanzibar, Dar es Salaam, Tanga, Mombasa, Portuguese East Africa, and Durban. Some of the captions are dated, variously between March 1904 and January 1907.

did.unittitle: Eastern and Central Africa. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Draper

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A portfolio of one hundred and twenty-two original photographs and two postcards compiled by the missionaries, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Draper, between 1903 and 1927. The images document the life and work at several different mission stations and leprosy colonies in the area.

did.unittitle: German East Africa: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: German East Africa: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album entitled "Kamera Bilder aus Deutschostafrika", apparently produced by Walther Dobbertinm Daressalam. Images date from circa 1896 to 1910, documenting all aspects of life in the early years of recently formed German colony on the African Equator.

did.unittitle: German East Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of two hundred and thirty-five original photographs, mostly snapshots, housed in two albums and one custom-made box. Photographs by an unidentified photographer, dating from 1896 to 1913 and documenting the life of German soldiers and settlers in a recently established colony with a focus on upcountry military and farming life, particularly in Usumbara and the northwestern Kilimanjaro area around Moshi.

did.unittitle: 62 photographs
1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: German East Africa: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

did.unittitle: 1 photograph album
Portuguese East Africa and the British Central African Protectorate: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Portuguese East Africa and the British Central African Protectorate: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album apparently compiled by "C.L.W" and containing images of the construction of the Shire Highlands Railway, as well as scenic views, images of a big game hunting safari, and two images of the grave of Dr. Livingstone's wife, Mary Moffat, at Shupunga.

did.unittitle: Portuguese East Africa, Zanzibar, Aden: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Portuguese East Africa, Zanzibar, Aden: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirteen albumen prints, with captions, recording a sea voyage up the east coast of Africa from Portuguese East Africa via Zanzibar and Aden.

did.unittitle: Portuguese East Africa, Mozambique: 38 photographs with related printed material
did.physloc: See: Portuguese East Africa, Mozambique: 38 photographs with related printed material (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A portfolio of thirty-eight original photographs, mostly by named photographers and dating from 1886 to 1911. Images portray diverse aspects of and different places in the Portuguese colony.

did.unittitle: Winston Churchill's Big-Game Safari in Uganda in 1907

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album compiled by Lieutenant C. E. Fishbourne, documenting a big-game hunting safari in Uganda undertaken by Winston Churchill in 1907, on which Fishbourne served as an escort, and including images of Churchill and other members of the party. Accompanying material includes a letter of condolence from Churchill written upon the death of Fishbourne in 1915.

did.unittitle: Uganda: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Uganda: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

did.unittitle: Churchill, Winston and others: correspondence
Zanzibar and Pemba: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Zanzibar and Pemba: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An album containing sixty-eight original photographs and one panoramic postcard, dating from 1896 to 1913 and containing views of ruined mosques and mosque interiors, views of Pemba and Zanzibar town, and ngoma images.

did.unittitle: Zanzibar and German East Africa: 20 albumen prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of photographs entitled "Erinnerung an die Deutsch-Afrikanische Messe den 6 und 7 März, 1895. Zum besten des Militär-Hilfsvereins."

did.unittitle: Zanzibar. Hansing & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of four albums compiled by a member of the Zanzibar branch of the Hamburg trading house of Hansing & Co., accompanied by five loose photographs

did.unittitle: Album A: 1 photograph album
did.physloc: See: Hansing & Company. Zanzibar: 1 photograph album (in Series II)

did.unittitle: Album B: 1 photograph album
Album C: 1 photograph album
Album D: 1 photograph album
Loose photographs
Panoramas and Photographers' Portfolios

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this series corresponds to that described in Chapter Two of the dealer catalog.

did.unittitle: Panoramas
did.physloc: See: Panoramas (in Series III)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes panoramas of Dar es Salaam, Lourenço Marques, Mombasa, Pangani, Tanga, and Zanzibar.

did.unittitle: Photographer's Portfolios
Coutinho Brothers-Zanzibar: 20 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of twenty images of diverse views and scenes of Zanzibar by Coutinho Brothers, Photographers of Main Road, Zanzibar. Images are unmounted and mostly captioned on the verso in English or German.

did.unittitle: Coutinho Brothers-Dar es Salaam: 18 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of eighteen original photographs of Dar es Salaam by Coutinho Brothers, Photographers of Main Road, Zanzibar and of Dar es Salaam. Images are unmounted and with manuscript captions on the verso.

did.unittitle: P. De Lord Brothers - Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar
did.physloc: See: P. De Lord - Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar (in Series III)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-four original photographs of scenes and views in Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar by P. De Lord Brothers, Photographers, Zanzibar.

did.unittitle: Walther Dobbertin - German East Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of twelve unmounted, original photographs, all untitled, by Walther Dobbertin, Post Buchholz, Kreis Hamburg, each bearing Dobbertin's stamp on the verso.

did.unittitle: [Walther Dobbertin?] - German East Africa
did.physloc: See: Walther Dobbertin-German East Africa (in Series III)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four large mounted, original photographs by unidentified photographer, which may be the work of Walther Dobbertin.

did.unittitle: A. C. Gomes & Co. - Zanzibar: 18 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of eighteen original photographs depicting aspects of life in Zanzibar in the 1890s and early 1900s by A. C. Gomes & Co., Zanzibar; each are stamped with some manuscript identifications on the verso.

did.unittitle: J. and J. & M. Lazarus-Portuguese East Africa
did.physloc: See also: J. and J. & M. Lazarus-Portuguese East Africa (in Series III)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of eleven original photographs by J. Lazarus or J. & M. Lazarus, and mostly of Lourenço Marques, Beira and Sofala.

did.unittitle: K. Ledermann-Zanzibar: 6 photographs
did.physloc: See: K. Ledermann-Zanzibar (in Series III)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of six original photographs by K. Ledermann, Zanzibar with captions and mounted in pairs on the recto and verso of thick card, disbound album leaves.

did.unittitle: A. Monteiro-German East Africa: 6 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six original photographs of A. Monteiro, Photographer Dar-es Salaam, unmounted and mostly uncaptioned.

did.unittitle: R. V. Periera-Tanga and German East Africa: 10 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A series of ten original photographs, all stamped "R. V. Periera, Photographer, Tanga, D. O. Africa" on the verso.

did.unittitle: C. Vincenti-Portfolio of trees, bushes, plants and crops

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A portfolio of botanical images all identified as being by, or attributed to, C. Vincenti of Dar es Salaam and dated from 1896 to 1910. The portfolio comprises a series of studies of some of the trees, fruits, and crops indigenous to the coastal area of German East Africa, together with agricultural crops such as sisal, sugar and tobacco which were introduced.

did.unittitle: Thematic collections

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this series corresponds to that described in Chapter Three of the dealer catalog.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs arranged thematically by the dealer.

Aspects of German Colonial Life: 35 photographs

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Empty cases
Magic Lantern Slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this series corresponds to that which is described in Chapter Six of the dealer catalog.

did.unittitle: East Africa and Zanzibar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A group of thirty (plus one duplicate) glass-mounted, magic lantern slides, some in color, the remainder in monochrome; each 7.5 x 7 cm. and depicting people and scenes in East Africa and Zanzibar. This group was put together from diverse sources, including Underwood and Underwood, by the Bureau of Visual Instruction, Chicago, Public Schools.

did.unittitle: Metal and glass lens for an antique lantern projector, contained in its original cardboard box
German East Africa (1 of 3)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A group of one hundred and fifty magic lantern slides housed in three partitioned boxes made of wood. A large majority of the slides are labelled "Walter Grimm, Photo-Werkstätten Dresden, Grunaer Strasse 3." Others are labelled: "Photozentrale des Kolonialkriegerdank G.m.b.H Berlin NW.6, Karlstr. 31." The images appear to be the work of more than one unidentified photographer, and Walter Grimm and Photozentrale seem to have been the makers of the slides. The images depict a wide range of places and scenes of life in German East Africa.
